text: Israel's Negev desert was all but barren
when the Ovitz family settled here
decades ago there was nothing here it
was all send so it was difficult in the
beginning
and eventually in things you know
developed develop so much that today the
Ovitz farm is now a 150-acre pepper and
tomato empire planted in the most
unlikely of places in the heart of this
oppressive climate Europe England and
Russia is our main customers Israel is
at the forefront of desert farming
thanks to a longtime focus on making the
most of every drop of water
modern drip irrigation was invented here
and the country has embraced recycling
sewage water for irrigation and more
recently desalination the farms offer a
model for other arid regions that want
to grow their own crops as food prices
continue to rise globally
but farmers are still experimenting with
ways to make the system even more
efficient we use the irrigation pipes
with a drippers and then with the
plastics that's what we use a drip
irrigation system conserves treated
sewage water plastic sheets prevent
evaporation and all of this yields
strategic crops that require small
amounts of water one of the ways that we
have here to control irrigation systems
it's using cellular phones in the Golan
Heights Roni kadar controls his drip
irrigation system with his cell phone I
can solve the problem from here and I
can rewrite him for example but there is
one thing he cannot control the weather
Israel's four-year drought has slashed
mr. kadar water supply almost in half
evidencing the risky business of desert
farming I think altogether it's a German
damaging about 30 or 40 percent of our
ability to throw them as a result mr.
kadar had to tear up his apple orchard
apples would yield relatively low
profits were the first to go but if the
drought persists other crops may be next
which leaves Israel with a vexing
question can it continue to farm the
desert the government thinks so and is
planning to vastly expand the amount of
recycled and desalinated water it
produces the ambitious experiment could
provide Israel with all the water it
needs by 2013 but skeptics question the
cost
